DOC.HEAD: People in the News

DOC.TEXT: Sylvester Stallone has sued an art broker for $5 million, claiming she led him to pay millions of dollars more than he should have for several artworks. The fraud and breach-of-contract suit, filed Tuesday, charges that Barbara Guggenheim persuaded Stallone to pay $1.8 million for a painting she told him was an excellent investment. After buying it sight unseen, the star of the ``Rocky'' and ``Rambo'' movies said he discovered that 25 percent to 30 percent of it had been restored or retouched and that its previous owner had tried for some time to sell it. Based on that painting, the suit charges, Stallone believes he also paid too much for several other works bought through Ms. Guggenheim. Ms. Guggenheim could not immediately be reached for comment. There is no Los Angeles-area phone listing for her.

Former Romanian gymnastics star Nadia Comaneci and her companion, Constantin Panait, have been avoiding family, fellow Romanians and even some people who want to help them. One of those who haven't heard from Nadia and Panait is Maria Panait. When Constantin ran off with Nadia, he left his wife with four young children and no money. ``I thought at least he would call for Christmas,'' she said Tuesday, ``but no.'' Sightings of the couple have been reported from all over. ``I heard West Palm Beach from one member of my congregation,'' said Father Traian Pedrescu, pastor of The Holy Trinity Romanian Orthodox Church in neighboring Mirmar, a gathering place for many of the estimated 5,000 Romanians in South Florida. ``But honestly, with what is happening now in our country, most of them would say, `Who cares?''' Mike Jacki, executive director of the U.S. Gymnastics Federation, expected to hear from Nadia. After her escape from Romania last month, the federation received more than a dozen offers for movies, books and appearances. ``And I'm almost willing to bet that to this day, she doesn't know a thing about them,'' Jacki said. ``We could never reach her to tell her, so we put it out through the media.''

Gov. Rose Mofford was released from the hospital Wednesday, nine days after emergency surgery to remove her gallbladder. Mrs. Mofford, 67, who checked into St. Joseph's Hospital and Medical Center on Dec. 17, said as she left the hospital that she was feeling good and ``anxious to get well.'' Press secretary Vada Manager said Mrs. Mofford has been walking around several times a day and doing some work from her hospital bed. Mrs. Mofford's doctors want her to spend two to three weeks recuperating at home before she returns to a full schedule at the Capitol, Manager said. But he said she still plans to deliver her State of the State message when the Legislature convenes Jan. 8.

Friends of Gov. Kay Orr are planning a birthday party for her Jan. 5, but the celebration will be a little more cozy than last year's. Some 3,000 people attended last year's party, held in a building on the state fairgrounds. This year's will be at an indoor sports complex at the University of Nebraska-Lincoln. ``It was 20 below and it got a little cold, that's why we moved it this year,'' said Bill Orr, the governor's husband. The governor will be 51 on Jan. 2. Friends in all 93 counties will bake birthday cakes. Admission is $10 per couple or $25 per family.
